 BOLIVIA ENVIRONMENT, INDUSTRY AND MINING PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT 1. BACKGROUND 1. In Bolivia, non-agnrcultural economic activity has been concentrated in mining, petroleum extraction, agricultural and forestry industries, textiles and light manufacturing. These activities, which will likely underpin the country's economic development in the medium-term, have grown with little concem for environmental protection or worker health and safety. In the case of mining, Bolivia has been a commercial producer (mainly silver, tin) since the sixteenth century. Since the 1950s, a significant share of the industry has been operated by COMIBOL, the State-owned mining company In response to the need for capital and management improvements, COMIBOL is withdrawing from production operations, and will remain as a contract administrator. It has reduced its operations. and has begun to offer its economically-viable mines and smelters for private participation. Some properties have been closed, others are being leased or offered for outright sale, or in the case of the Vinto smelter, for inclusion in the Government's Capitalization Program. The latter Program is designed to attract private investment into key State-owned enterprises, and to distribute Government- owned shares to privately-managed pension funds for the benefit of the Bolivian population. IDA is supporting mining sector restructuring under the ongoing Mining Sector Rehabilitation Project, and the wider Capitalization Program through the Capitalization Program Adjustment Credit. The mining sector restructuring aims at establishing an enabling environment for private development of the sector, based on the reform and modernization of the legal and institutional framework. In the case of industry, apart from three cement plants, manufacturing is relatively underdeveloped, though medium and smaller-scale operations exist near major cities. Principal activities center on textiles, leather products, food and beverage products and wood processing. A. Environmental Pollution from Industry 2. In the case of industry, pollution originates mainly from the discharge of untreated effluents to rivers or inadequate municipal sewage systems. Instances of localized air pollution also arise in mining and industry, e.g. from smelters, refineries, or cement plants. B. Environmental Conditions in Mining Communities 3. In the COMIBOL mining centers that would be covered by the Project -- namely Oruro (San Jose mine), Potosi (IJnificada mine), Llallagua (Siglo XX mine and Catavi smelter), Santa Fe, Huanuni, Colquiri, and Caracoles, and others -- past and ongoing mining activities have created numerous sources of contamination which affect surface water (and in some cases, groundwater), air, and soil. Tailings from the mills, waste rock, underground and open-pit mine workings, roads, wastewater ponds, landfills, and smelters are among the potential existing sources of mining-related pollution Of
 2 particular concern are those sources which generate very low-pH water (acid rock drainage or ARD), which dissolves and transports metals, such as lead, arsenic, cadmium, and zinc, which may pose a threat to human health and the environment. Acid rock drainage discharges from mine entryways (adits), and seeps from the tailings and rock piles. The nature, extent, and impact of ARD varies greatly, however. The environmental degradation associated with ARD is determined by many factors, including water chemistry in receiving streams and rivers, dilution and temperature. 4. In addition, mine waste has been used extensively in mining communities to build impoundments, roads, and common areas such as playgrounds and sports fields. Many of these structures continue to release metals through the acid-generating process. Inhabitants of the mining communities frequently come into direct contact with the mine waste; children play on or adjacent to tailings and waste rock piles, and people build houses directly on old tailings. However it is important to note that contact -- even direct contact -- does not presuppose risk. Mine waste is highly variable, both in toxicity and in bioavailability. For example, some forms of arsenic or of lead are not readily absorbed into the human body, and therefore do not pose a significant risk to human health. 5. The environment in mining towns is also polluted by the contaminants typical of poor communities in many developing countries. For example, drinking water is frequently contaminated with bacteria and fecal coliform, and ambient air is contaminated with dust from industrial and combustion sources, lead from smelters and vehicle exhaust, and sulfur dioxide from smelters. In many mining communities, these pollutants may be causing more damage to human health than heavy metal pollution from mining. 6. In the context of restructuring the mining sector, COMIBOL is commissioning environmental audits for a priority set of fourteen mining properties. The first three audits, respectively for Oruro (San Jose mine), Huanuni, and Colquiri have been completed; the rest are expected to be completed by December 1995. In addition, the ongoing Oruro Pilot Project being carried out through the Secretariat of Mines is conducting an environmental assessment of an important mining region of Bolivia which contains several COMIBOL properties. Together, these studies will identify major environmental problems at various sites, provide data to inform the assignment of environmental liabilities between parties to divestment transactions, and define cost-effective, site-specific, remediation plans. The recommendations for remediation emanating from the environmental audits for San Jose, Huanuni and Colquiri are summarized in Annex 8, and in the Project File. C. Institutional Framework for Environmental Management 7. Due to growing environmental concern, in 1991/92 the (then) Government established the National Secretariat for the Environment (SENMA) with IDA support. It also issued a National Environmental Action Plan and passed an umbrella Environmental Law. The present Government has indicated its commitment to environmental management by establishing a Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment (MSDE). The MSDE -- which absorbed SENMA and the Planning Ministry -- is charged with formulating and implementing national policies to encourage development with concem for the environment. Presently, MSDE, through its Subsecretariat of Environment, (which is responsible for EIA and enforcement activities), is promulgating initial national environmental Regulations covering EIA, air, water, and solid and hazardous wastes. However, the staff of MSDE is
 3 still small and has limited practical experience. Moreover, the baseline information, laboratory capacity, and environmental management policies and concrete action plans based on a sound assessment of environmental priorities at the national and regional levels all remain to be refined. IDA, IDB and bilateral donors are supporting MSDE's programs, which now need to be made tangible inter alia through institutional strengthening of MSDE and line agencies; development of baseline data and procedures to support EA and compliance monitoring of greenfield and ongoing operations; implementation, and ultimately refinement, of sectoral environmental regulations, standards, and codes of practice; strengthening of environmental testing laboratories, (so that locally-conducted analyses have credibility in Bolivia and abroad, and are able to support a national environmental monitoring system); and improvement of the Government's capacity to communicate to stakeholders concerning risks to health and the environment due to pollution. Moreover, both the Government and the private sector need assistance to identify and make cost-effective firm-level investments to abate pollution from sources for which they are liable under the emerging regulatory regime. The IDB has approved a project for MSDE aimed at strengthening its management systems and staffing, especially outside La Paz. IL THlE PROJECT A. Project Objectives 8. The Project would: (i) support the implementation and refinement of a regulatory framework to assure that privately-led mining and industrial activities grow in a more environmentally-friendly fashion; (ii) help remediate contamination from past mining activities for which the State accepts liability, including remediation activities that help facilitate private investment in the mining sector; and (iii) assist in attracting non-Project resources (e.g. from the FIS, FNDR, or FDC') for investments which are not eligible for financing under the Project in mining communities, in order to address urgent environmental problems, e.g. for potable water and sanitation. B. Project Description 9. The Project has been designed based upon the findings of a 1993 sectoral environmental assessment for the mining and industrial sectors, as well as a number of studies carried out during Project preparation (e.g. on the adequacy of laboratory testing services; on the treatment of environmental liabilities in the privatization process; and on the development of risk-based selection criteria for publicly-funded remediation investments in mining). The Project would include components as follows: I Bolivia has established, inter alia with IDA financing, a number of programs to assist municipalities and rural areas address their most serious environmental problems -- contaminated drinking water and dust containing lead, arsenic, cadmium, and zinc -- by providing basic infrastructure. These programs fund activities such as water sanitation systems and road paving.

Costs are based upon professional judgments regarding manpower inputs, unit costs, and the likely absorptive capacity of related institutions during the Project period. 3. Remediation Investments 14. A list of mine sites to be considered as possible candidates for environmental improvement interventions has been prepared on the basis of risk-based eligibility criteria tailored to the mining sector (Annex 8 and Project File). These criteria included, inter alia, the impact that mining pollution would reasonably have on human health, economic activities or ecosystems for each site. For each of these sites, environmental audits would provide information to identify a range of environmental management measures (e.g. potable water, sanitation, urban paving for dust control, remediation of mine tailing piles, control of the flow of acid mine drainage etc.) which show promise of yielding the highest benefits for the resources used, if carried out in the specific locale (Annex 8 and Project File). The highest yielding -- and therefore priority -- measures may or may not, in any specific mining community, include remediation of contamination from past mining activities. The Project would finance, on a pilot basis, only those eligible subprojects comprising priority environmental management measures which (i) had their origin in mining activities; (ii) were the responsibility of the State under Bolivia's environmental liability provisions; and (iii) could not be addressed with financing through established municipal and rural improvement programs, such as the FIS, FNDR, or FDC. The Project would assist communities in accessing non-Project sources of funding for priority investments which did not satisfy the above-mentioned eligibility criteria by financing consultants (promotores) who would be employed by the Secretariat of Mines. These consultants would work with the mining communities to identify and prepare projects for funding from various non-Project financing sources. Project activities would not therefore duplicate ongoing municipal improvement initiatives, nor violate the established investment planning process at the municipal level. 15. An initial set of environmental management measures which demonstrate primafacie promise of yielding adequate economic returns, has been agreed with MSDE and MED to be considered for the San Jose, Huanuni and Colquiri mines, and is included in Annex 8 and the Project File. Detailed plans for the remediation activities, and associated cost-benefit studies would be prepared for each eligible subproject, and those investments with acceptable economic returns would be proposed to IDA for financing under the Project. In addition, the Project would finance remediation activities that remove impediments to private investment in COMIBOL mines in those cases where legal remedies would be insufficient to aUleviate concerns of private investors about liability for past contamination, and cleanup by COMIBOL would be demonstrably cost-effective. The methodology for carrying out cost- benefit studies, and associated investment decision criteria, would be included in an Operational Manual to be adopted under the Project as a condition of Effectiveness (para. 27). 16. The initial set (Annex 8) of eligible subprojects for possible financing under the Project for San Jose in Oruro consists of selective tailings remediation, channeling and treatment of acid mine drainage, and remediation of physical threats in old mine operations. In Huanuni and Colquiri, audits have also identified environmental improvements likely to be justifiable at those sites. However, the final designation of activities for possible financing under the Project would only be made once negotiations

Technical Assistance and Training to Support Environmental Management in Mining 18. The Project would include financing for consulting services, equipment and training to assist the Secretariat of Mining to improve environmental management in the mining sector, and COMIBOL to benefit from technical studies related to preparation of eligible subprojects (para. 14), as well as to inform its broader environmental management efforts in its various mines. The activities to be supported under the Project would complement those environmentally-related activities being supported under the MSRP, and would include: (i) development of procedures for mine permitting, inspection, enforcement reclamation and closure, including methods of financial assurance; (ii) development and dissemination of Codes of Practice to enable mine operators to comply with emergent environmental regulations; (iii) assistance to develop environmental monitoring programs to collect data on ambient air, water, and soil conditions, and on human health impacts at various COMIBOL mine sites; (iv) basic hydrological studies for various COMIBOL mine sites, inter alia to enable COMIBOL to prepare mitigation plans for properties to be transferred to the private sector, or closed. Hydrological data would also be used to complement data sets on geology and geochemistry which are being developed in conjunction with a pilot Geographic Information System (GIS) under the ongoing MSRP, and would thereby further the capacity of the GIS to inform site-specific environmental risk assessment in the mining sector. This would open up possibilities for more efficient environmental regulation of mining operations; and (v) engineering designs for remediation interventions at COMIBOL mines. The program is estimated to cost US$4.5 million (20% of total Project costs). C. Rationale for IDA Involvement 19. The Project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) presented to the Board on February 8, 1994. The Bank Group strategy reflected in the CAS focuses on eliminating the remaining structural constraints to growth and expanding the availability of resources for poverty and
 8 human capital development within a sustainable environment. The lending program included in the CAS contemplates projects falling within three categories: (i) rationalizing the role of the State, (ii) poverty and human resource development; and (iii) environment and natural resource management. The proposed Project includes programs germane to two of the previously-mentioned categories, namely assisting the Government to meet its environmental liabilities arising from privatization, and fostering private development of the mining and industrial sectors in a more environmentally-friendly fashion. IDA's ongoing cross-sectoral involvement in industrial, mining, and environmental issues in Bolivia piaces it in a unique position to mobilize efforts to address the complex issues involved with pollution abatement there. D. Program Objective Categories 20. The Project would contribute to IDA's environrnent, and private and public sector reform categones. E. Environmental Aspects 21. The Project is classified as a "B" project, owing to its focus on environmental improvement. Its design is based on a sectoral environmental assessment (EA) for the mining and industrial sectors, which was financed by the Government of Sweden and prepared in 1992/93 in consultation with over forty organizations, including major NGOs. Major findings of the EA were that: (i) there were significant problems with water pollution; (ii) forthcoming steps to "privatize" COMIBOL's rmines provided an important opportunity to improve environmental management in mining; and (iii) programs should be encouraged to improve knowledge of environmental conditions, strengthen environmental management, and develop consensual approaches for compliance. Benefits and Risks 48. In the short run, the Project would help remediate priority environmental problems in mining communities. This would yield economic benefits from improvements in human health, economic infrastructure, or ecosystems, and from the removal of impediments to fresh private investments, which would raise incomes. While economic returns from the various remediation subprojects would depend upon local conditions, investments in several other Bank and IDA-supported environmental projects have estimated rates of retums exceeding 20% arising from improvements in human health. The Project would also help upgrade testing laboratory capabilities, thus assisting with development of a credible national environmental monitoring capacity. In the medium-term, the Project would help build policy and institutional capacity to mitigate future pollution flows in mining and industry. It would also help improve worker health and safety conditions in existing and future mining and industrial enterprises. In the longer-term, through its programs to encourage pollution prevention at the firm level, the Project would facilitate development of more efficient and sustainable mining and industrial sectors. Moreover, through training programs for counterparts during implementation of various studies, the Project would help strengthen the national manpower base in environmental management. 49. The major technical risk is that the project design would be inappropriate. This risk has been managed by basing it on the findings of a sectoral EA, and reviewing Project components carefully with stakeholders. The major economic risk is that remediation funds would be misallocated. This has been managed by agreeing with the Secretariat of Mines upon a methodology and a set of criteria that would be applied to select only those investments that would have high benefits relative to costs for financing under the Project (Annex 8). The major implementation risks are that: (i) MSDE's limited institutional capacity and experience with IDA and NDF projects may lead to delays in inter- institutional coordination and Project execution; (ii) identification and implementation of investments under the remediation component may be delayed and Project disbursements may lag; and (iv) lack of
 19 counterpart funds could delay execution of remediation works. These risks will, respectively, be managed by: (i) providing a team of consultants to advise the ECU; reviewing IDA and NDF procedures carefully with counterparts during Project preparation and start-up; and agreeing upon standard procurement documents early in the Project; (ii) agreeing upon a core program of remediation activities in the mining sector, and a priority set of activities under the laboratory upgrading program during Project preparation; and (iii) financing an ample share of remediation investment costs from external sources, and reviewing forthcoming counterpart funding requirements during annual reviews timed to inform annual budget decisions.  32 Annex 8 Page 1 of 6 BOLIVIA ENVIRONMENT, INDUSTRY AND MINING PROJECT Selection of Sub-Projects for Inclusion under the Environmental Remediation Component of the Project I. Process A process has been established for the selection of priority investments under the EIMP. This process contains two major steps, which are detailed in two documents in the Project File. The first involves selecting the priority mine sites on the basis of the risks they pose to human health and the environment. The second step involves choosing thepriority investments and activities at a particular site. The objective of the process is to identify the enviromnental problems which have high human and economic costs and the investments likely to provide the largest benefits for the money spent5. H. Selecting priority sites The key steps in selecting priority sites can be summarized as follows. Stage I: Preparing an inventory of sites and ranking the sites by their hazard potential The first step in setting priorities is to compile an inventory of the universe of mines/facilities under consideration for inclusion in the Project. This includes simple basic information such as the size of the mine, the minerals extracted, and the size of the population likely to be exposed to environmental pollutants. The sites in the inventory are then scored using a set of numerical criteria to identify the sites which are likely to pose the most serious threat to human welfare and the environment. The scoring system is weighted towards those sites which may generate significant quantities of major pollutants and which may expose a large population to health damage and economic loss. 5 The two steps are described in detail in the reports "Selecting Sites for Remediation of Environmental Problems due to Mining in Bolivia" (Draft, October 1995), and "Selecting Highest Priority Investments for Environmental Management in Mining Communities in Bolivia" (Draft, October 1995).
 33 Annex 8 Page 2 of 6 Stage 2: Investigating priority sites This stage involves visiting the sites that have been identified in Stage 1 as "priority sites" in order to confirm the initial identification and to assess the nature and extent of hazards present that may warrant remediation. The initial visits provide quick overviews or "rapid environmental assessments" of site conditions, based on visual inspection and collection of immediately available information. It is intended that the assessments should last no longer than a day or two. Field workers record the physical conditions at the site, note any evidence of chemical contamination and would provide a first estimate of the severity of the danger to human inhabitants or to the environment. It is essential that the assessment cover not only the site itself but also the areas surrounding the site which may have been affected by contamination from the mine. Stage 3: Assessing the nature and extent of environmental damage at the site Sites judged to be a source of serious damage are targeted for a more complete assessment of environmental conditions (usually called an "audit"). In addition to providing information on the sources of pollution and possible remediation options, these audits would focus on the human and economic impacts of the contamination in as much detail as possible. The audits must include impacts occurring outside the mining property (off-site effects). The main economic impacts to consider are human health, materials damage, and ecosystem damage. For example, human health problems can be caused by exposure to environmental pollutants in the air, water, soil, and food. In Bolivia, the main contaminants from mining harming human health are likely to be lead in the air, water, soil, and food, arsenic in the air and water, cadmium in the water and food, and, to a lesser extent, cyanide in the air and water. Therefore, to ascertain whether the mining contamination is damaging health, the audit would provide data on drinking water quality, ambient air quality, and data on food and soil contarnination and data on human health. m. Choosing investments and activities for environmental management at a particular site The information in the audits on sources of pollution and on the damages caused provide the basis for determining those remedial investments which should be given priority. The basic principle is that priority be given to those investments which provide the greatest improvement in human health and environmental conditions for the money spent. As far as possible, the benefits would be expressed in monetary terms. Where this is not possible, the benefits would be expressed in terms of physical impacts, such as number of cases of illness avoided, number of bushels of crops saved, etc. The list of possible actions is then ranked in terms of the benefits and costs of each proposal. There will be uncertainty in the quantification of the benefits but the methodology produces, at a minimum, a grouping of projects according to estimated benefits, even where it is difficult to produce strict rankings for each project. The selected projects are those which have high benefits, low cost and a predicted high level of effectiveness and reliability.
 34 Annex 8 Page 3 of 6 IV. Present Status It is planned to carry out environmental audits on fifteen properties. As of July 1995, four of these audits have been completed. The remaining eleven should be completed by December 1995. On the basis of the available information, including inspections of some of the sites and discussions with relevant experts within the industry, a preliminary set of remediation actions has been identified for the priority sites. This preliminary list is based on identified areas of high health impact and significant damage due to past mining and on advice from mining specialists on remedial actions. The actions included are those which have high returns to the remediation investments, based on present information. The list will be reviewed and will be revised as necessary as additional environmental audits and other studies -- such as the Oruro Pilot Project -- are completed. The preliminary investment proposals have been discussed with both the Secretariat of Mines and the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Environment and are considered to address the most important problems arising from environmental contamination due to mining. Not all the high priority activities will be financed under the Project, however. The Project would finance, on a pilot basis, only those priority subprojects for environmental management which (i) had their origin in mining activities; (ii) were the responsibility of the State under Bolivia's environmental liability provisions; and (iii) could not be addressed with financing from other sources, such as FIS, FNDR, and FDC. In addition, the Project would finance remediation activities that remove impediments to private investment in COMIBOL mines in those cases where legal remedies would be insufficient to alleviate concerns of private investors about liability for past contamination, and cleanup by COMIBOL would be demonstrably cost- effective. The methodology for carrying out the cost-benefit studies, and the associated investment decision criteria, would be included in an Operational Manual to be adopted under the Project and applied during Project execution. doc.repnme: Bolivia - Environment, Industry and Mining Project
doc.abstracts: The Environment, Industry and Mining Project will: 1) support the implementation and refinement of a regulatory framework to assure that privately-led mining and industrial activities grow in a more environmentally-friendly fashion; 2) help remediate contamination from past mining activities for which the state accepts liability, including remediation activities that help facilitate private investment in the mining sector; and 3) assist in attracting non-project resources for investments which are not eligible for financing under the project in mining communities, in order to address urgent environmental problems, e.g. for potable water and sanitation. The project will include the following components: 1) studies to support the development of the regulatory framework, which will include basic data collection and policy development implementation; 2) laboratory upgrading for the implementation of a program to foster development of credible laboratory testing services in Bolivia; 3) remediation investments, which will be done on a pilot basis and only for those eligible subprojects comprising priority environmental management measures; and 4) technical assistance and training to support environmental management in mining.
